results.title: Childhood memories of Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a tribute to her mother, the Indigenous activist Eleanor Harding, Deborah Deacon tells of her life and various struggles. Wanting a better life for her family was the main motivation in Eleanor moving from her home in Queensland to Melbourne. She eventually found a community in Fitzroy who supported her when she needed it at the start. Eleanor never forgot this, and devoted her life to helping out the community in various ways throughout her life. Her mother, as well as the elders of her community, have instilled in Deborah a strong sense of both individual and community empowerment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Inheriting
results.brief_description: Arika Waulu has inherited quite a lot in her young life. A young fighter for social justice, her inheritance is two-fold. She inherited her land from her ancestors and her sense of social justice from her parents. But rather than take these things for granted, Arika embraces them.

results.title: The Parachute workers
results.creator_credit: Peg Osborne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Despite being discouraged, Peg Osborne wanted to contribute to Australia’s World War II effort. She joined the air force and was sent to Bairnsdale as a textile worker. She reflects on her time there, the work, relations with the male workers, and the sorrows as well as the humour that keep everyone’s spirits up and the friends that Peg will never forget.

results.title: The Traveller
results.creator_credit: John Hansen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: John Hansen’s war experience really started after World War II. Having been seconded into the US Navy, John was there to celebrate in the streets of California when the war ended. Then he travelled the world, transporting a variety of things, from war brides to coal. In the end, the world became his classroom.

results.title: The Yellow-box eucalypt
results.creator_credit: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Des Surkitt pays tribute to the 27 fallen soldiers in one of the worst accidents in the Australian Army’s history. In Kapooka, an explosion during a training exercise, took the lives of all but one of the young soldiers. This event had a profound effect on Des, more so as he had just completed the training program the week before. Despite his good fortune, Des honours these lost men and reflects on why they have been forgotten by their own country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When he went to the cinemas, the newsreels would beckon David Higgins to ‘Join the Navy and see the world!’. And join the Navy he did, serving in the Mediterranean during World War II. He guides us through the bowels of the ship and the claustrophobic conditions therein. David also reflects on the life-shifting experience of war, how it changed his perspective on things and how little he knew at the time when he signed up.
results.title_for_label: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

David also reflects on the life-shifting experience of war, how it changed his perspective on things and how little he knew at the time when he signed up.

results.title: One hour and twelve minutes left to live
results.creator_credit: Charlie Safstrom, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Charlie Safstrom served as a sniper in Borneo during World War II. Here he recounts one of the more frightening moments of his service where he was almost mistaken for a Japanese soldier during a late night changing of the guard.
results.title_for_label: One hour and twelve minutes left to live

results.title: Signals : nerves of the army
results.creator_credit: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: During the war, without communication, the soldiers were sitting ducks. Signalmen, like Bruce Christie, may not have been on the front line, but, as Bruce illustrates, their role was just as crucial to the war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: [Reginald Relf]
results.creator_credit: Reginald Relf, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Reginald Relf tells of his time in the Royal Australian Air Force, training as a mechanic at RMIT in Melbourne. Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Reginald Relf, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Reginald Relf tells of his time in the Royal Australian Air Force, training as a mechanic at RMIT in Melbourne. Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.
description_for_label: Reginald Relf tells of his time in the Royal Australian Air Force, training as a mechanic at RMIT in Melbourne. Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.

results.title: One of thousands
results.creator_credit: Ralph Basson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a veteran who served in Normandy during World War II, Ralph Basson takes us on a sensory tour of war. In this, Ralph highlights the things you cling to in order to survive. ‘With all the chaos going on around you, you have to remember your training and just put one foot in front of the other’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Basson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
